MWC.GUI.SplitPanel

Class PaneLayout

  • java.lang.Object
    • MWC.GUI.SplitPanel.PaneLayout
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.LayoutManager, java.awt.LayoutManager2

    public class PaneLayout
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.awt.LayoutManager2
    A Pane Layout Manager Maintains a binary tree of child components. First split divides the whole space horizontally or vertically, next split divides these splits further. Components can be added either in a default (and not very useful) way by using add(). This method traverses the right hand nodes of the layout tree until it encounters a leaf. This leaf is then split 50:50 in the opposite way from its parent and the new node inserted. The other way to add components is to specifiy a PaneConstaints object which specifies the component to split, whether to split horizontally and the proportion of the space to take from the component that is being split When the window is resized, all the proportions are maintained as best as possible. Programmatic modifictaion of the proportions at runtime are accomplished via setConstraints(Component, PaneConstaint) . For a UI to modifify proportions, use borland.jbcl.control.SplitPanel. Further work: - implement docking of windows (at present they are just zero width) - implement undocking of windows into different orders - improve the message handling to get sharper performance - may ultimately need a more complex alogrithm - current binary tree may look a little wacky under some conditions
    Version:
    1.0, 25 Sept 1995
    Author:
    David Williams

      • setGap

        public void setGap(int gap)
        The number of pixels that will surround each component the actual size of a divider will be twice this number SplitPanel uses this area to allow the user to change the relative sizes of the components by clicking and dragging on this area. Default is 0.
